<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks';
	}
</script>

	<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v23.1 (Yoast SEO v23.1) - https://yoast.com/wordpress/plugins/seo/ -->
	<title>The Fractured Statue Campaign: U.S. Government Agency Targeted in Spear-Phishing Attacks</title>
	<meta name="description" content="Unit 42 observed several malware families typically associated with the Konni Group primarily targetting a US government agency at the height of the US interacting with North Korea." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks/" />

	<meta property="og:title" content="The Fractured Statue Campaign: U.S. Government Agency Targeted in Spear-Phishing Attacks" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="Unit 42 observed several malware families typically associated with the Konni Group primarily targetting a US government agency at the height of the US interacting with North Korea." />

<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Adrian McCabe"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/amccabepaloaltonetworks-com/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="CARROTBALL,CARROTBAT,Fractured Statue,KONNI,phishing,Syscon"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/unit42-carrot-ball-blog-banner-r1_d3-380x184.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"The Fractured Statue Campaign: U.S. Government Agency Targeted in Spear-Phishing Attacks","name":"The Fractured Statue Campaign: U.S. Government Agency Targeted in Spear-Phishing Attacks","description":"Unit 42 observed several malware families typically associated with the Konni Group primarily targetting a US government agency at the height of the US interacting with North Korea.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks\/","datePublished":"January 23, 2020","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nBetween July and October 2019, Unit 42 observed several malware families typically associated with the Konni Group (see Attribution section below for more details) used to primarily target a US government agency, using the ongoing and heightened geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea to lure targets into opening malicious email attachments. The malware families used in this campaign consisted mainly of malicious documents featuring CARROTBAT downloaders with SYSCON payloads, but also included a new malware downloader Unit 42 has dubbed CARROTBALL.\r\n\r\nCARROTBALL, initially discovered in an attack during October 2019, is a simple FTP downloader utility which facilitates the installation of SYSCON, a full-featured Remote Access Trojan (RAT) which leverages FTP for Command and Control (C2). It was found embedded in a malicious Word document sent as a phishing lure to a US government agency and two non-US foreign nationals professionally associated with North Korea.\r\n\r\nThroughout the course of the campaign, Unit 42 ultimately observed a total of six unique malicious document lures being sent as attachments from four unique Russian email addresses to 10 unique targets. The subject matter of the lures featured articles written in Russian pertaining to ongoing geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea. Of those malicious documents, five contained CARROTBAT downloaders, and one contained a CARROTBALL downloader. All malicious second stage payloads were SYSCON.\r\n\r\nWhile this campaign does demonstrate some evolution in the actor\u2019s tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) with the use of a new downloader family and new malicious code in the form of Word Document macros, the majority of its attributes bear a strong resemblance to the Fractured Block campaign previously reported by Unit 42 in November 2018. As such, Unit 42 has dubbed this campaign Fractured Statue. The Adversary Playbook for the activity described in this blog can be found here.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 1. Fractured Statue Campaign Timeline\r\n\r\nOpening Wave of Attacks\r\nBetween July 15th, 2019 and July 17th, 2019, spear phishing emails were sent to a total of five individuals at a US government agency from the email addresses 0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru and kargarnova@mail[.]ru. The spear phishing emails utilized three different email subjects with malicious macro documents attached with the same name; all file names were written in Russian. Further, all of the malicious documents contained articles written in Russian pertaining to ongoing geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea. The documents themselves were rather generic and had no embedded image enticements to enable macros. They did, however, leverage second-stage downloader components consistent with known CARROTBAT samples, and almost all of them featured SYSCON payloads. The first pages of each of these documents are shown below:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 2. First page of initial malicious document observed in the campaign. \r\n\r\nAssociated with CARROTBAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nTranslated Subject\r\nFile name\r\nTranslated File Name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\n4c201f9949804e90f94fe91882cb8aad3e7daf496a7f4e792b9c7fed95ab0726\r\n\u041e \u0441\u0438\u0442\u0443\u0430\u0446\u0438\u0438 \u043d\u0430 \u041a\u043e\u0440\u0435\u0439\u0441\u043a\u043e\u043c \u043f\u043e\u043b\u0443\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0435 \u0438 \u043f\u0435\u0440\u0441\u043f\u0435\u043a\u0442\u0438 \u0432\u0430\u0445 \u0434\u0438\u0430\u043b\u043e\u0433\u0430 \u043c\u0435\u0436\u0434\u0443 \u0421\u0428\u0410 \u0438 \u041a \u041d\u0414\u0420\r\n0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru\r\nOn the situation on the Korean Peninsula and the prospects for dialogue between the USA and the PDR\r\n\u041e \u0441\u0438\u0442\u0443\u0430\u0446\u0438\u0438 \u043d\u0430 \u041a\u043e\u0440\u0435\u0439\u0441\u043a\u043e\u043c\r\nAbout the situation in Korean\r\nhandicap.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. First phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nFigure 3. First page of second malicious document observed in the campaign.\r\n Associated with CARROTBAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nTranslated Subject\r\nFile name\r\nTranslated File Name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\n63c3817a5e9984aaf59e8a61ddd54793ffed11ac5becef438528447f6b2823af\r\n\u041f\u0440\u043e\u0434\u043b\u0438\u0442\u0441\u044f \u043b\u0438 \u043c\u0438\u0440\u043d\u0430\u044f \u043f\u0430\u0443\u0437 \u0430 \u043d\u0430 \u041a\u043e\u0440\u0435\u0439\u0441\u043a\u043e\u043c \u043f\u043e\u043b\u0443\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0440\u043e \u0432\u0435 \u0434\u043e 2024 \u0433\u043e\u0434\u0430\r\n0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru\r\nWill there be a peaceful pause on the Korean Peninsula until 2024?\r\n\u041f\u0440\u043e\u0434\u043b\u0438\u0442\u0441\u044f \u043b\u0438 \u043c\u0438\u0440\u043d\u0430\u044f \u043f\u0430\u0443\u0437\r\nWill the peace breaks last\r\nhandicap.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. Second phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nFigure 4. First page of third malicious document observed in the campaign. \r\nAssociated with CARROTBAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nTranslated Subject\r\nFile name\r\nTranslated File Name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\n9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225\r\n\u0420\u043e\u0441\u0441\u0438\u044f \u2013 \u041a\u041d\u0414\u0420 \u2013 \u0420\u041a \u2013 \u0442\u043e\u0440 \u0433\u043e\u0432\u043e-\u044d\u043a\u043e\u043d\u043e\u043c\u0438\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0435 \u0441\u0432\u044f\u0437 \u0438 \u2013 \u0438\u043d\u0432\u0435\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0446\u0438\u0438.\r\nkargarnova@mail[.]ru\r\n\u201cRussia - DPRK - RK - trade and economic ties and - investments.\u201d\r\n\u0420\u043e\u0441\u0441\u0438\u044f \u2013 \u041a\u041d\u0414\u0420 \u2013 \u0420\u041a \u2013 \u0442\u043e\u0440\r\nRussia - DPRK - RK - tor\r\nhandicap.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 3. Third phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nSecond Wave\r\nRoughly one month later, beginning on August 15, 2019 and ending on September 14, 2019, the second wave of CARROTBAT attacks occurred against three additional email addresses at the same government agency. One attack featured the same sender and malicious document but had a different subject and filename. The other two emails contained a previously unseen malicious document and featured a mix of Russian and English languages in both the document lures and the email correspondence.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nFile name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\n9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225\r\nRussia \u2013 North Korea \u2013 Republic of Korea \u2013 trade and economic relations \u2013 investments.\r\nkargarnova@mail[.]ru\r\nRussia \u2013 North Korea \u2013 Republic of Korea\r\nhandicap.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 4. Fourth phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nFigure 5. First page of fourth malicious document observed in the campaign. Associated with CARROTBAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nFile name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\ned63e84985e1af9c4764e6b6ca513ec1c16840fb2534b86f95e31801468be67a\r\nRepublic of Korea, the Russian Federation and the DPRK\r\nrusrnirasaf@yandex[.]ru\r\nRepublic of Korea, the Russian Federation and the DPRK.doc\r\npanda2019.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 5. Fifth phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nFigure 6. First page of the fifth malicious document observed in the campaign. Associated with CARROTBAT.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nTranslated Subject\r\nFile name\r\nTranslated File Name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\na4f858c6b54683d3b7455c9adcf2bb6b7ddc1f4d35d0f8f38a0f131c60d1790f\r\n\u041a\u043e\u0440\u0435\u0439\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0439 \u043f\u043e\u043b\u0443\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0440\u043e\u0432 \u0432 \u0433\u043b\u043e\u0431\u0430\u043b\u044c\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u0438 \u0440\u0435\u0433\u0438\u043e\u043d\u0430\u043b\u044c\u043d\u044b\u0445\u0438\u0437\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f\u0445. \u0411\u0435\u0437\u043e\u043f\u0430\u0441\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u044c \u0438\u0432\u043e\u0437\u043c\u043e\u0436\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0432\u0437\u0430\u0438\u043c\u043e\u0434\u0435\u0439\u0441\u0442\u0432\u0438\u044f\r\nkargarnova@mail[.]ru\r\nThe Korean Peninsula in global and regional dimensions. Security and Interoperability\r\n\u043c\u0430\u0442\u0435\u0440\u0438\u0430\u043b\u044b.doc\r\nmaterials.doc\r\npanda2019.eu5[.]org\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 6. Sixth phishing attempt details.\r\n\r\nFinal Attempt\r\nOn October 29, 2019, one of the same individuals targeted in the second wave of attacks was targeted again with a malicious document, though in this attack the sender was different and the document lure did not feature CARROTBAT. Also of note is that the lure in this attack did feature a more traditional \u201cenable macro\u201d cover page, but was then followed by additional pages in Russian that thematically matched with the documents found in the rest of the campaign.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 7. First page of sixth malicious document observed in the campaign. Associated with CARROTBALL.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nSubject\r\nSender\r\nTranslated Subject\r\nFile name\r\nTranslated File Name\r\nInitial C2 Domain\r\n\r\n\r\nc1a9b923fc1f81d69bd0494d296c75887e4a0f9abfc1cdfbfa9c0f4ab6c95db7\r\n\u0418\u043d\u0432\u0435\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0439 \u043a\u043b\u0438\u043c\u0430\u0442 \u0421\u0435\u0432\u0435\u0440\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u041a\u043e\u0440\u0435\u0438.\r\npryakhin20l0@mail[.]ru\r\n\u201cThe investment climate of North Korea.\u201d\r\n\u0418\u043d\u0432\u0435\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0439 \u043a\u043b\u0438\u043c\u0430\u0442 \u0421\r\nInvestment climate C\r\ndownplease.c1[.]biz\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 7. Seventh phishing attempt details.\r\nAlso interesting to note is that the sender added multiple recipients to their email; one was an individual at a US government agency, and the other two individuals were non-US foreign nationals professionally associated with ongoing activities in North Korea.\r\nTechnical Analysis\r\nWith the exception of the October 2019 attack, all of the malicious documents found in this campaign featured the following macro code snippet of interest:\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 8. Macro from malicious documents associated with CARROTBAT.\r\nWhen executed, this code will:\r\n\r\n \tDetermine whether the victim\u2019s host machine is running Windows with an x86 or x64 architecture.\r\n \tParse the contents of a corresponding textbox within the document and convert it to a command line argument specific to the Windows architecture on the victim\u2019s machine.\r\n \tExecute the command.\r\n \tClear the contents of the textboxes and save the document.\r\n\r\nAs previously mentioned, all samples featuring the macros above also featured CARROTBAT as a second stage downloader.\r\n\r\nThe October 2019 attack, however, differed significantly from the previous ones. Instead of reading from the contents of the document itself, the macros leveraged an embedded Windows executable in the form of hex bytes delimited via the \u2018|\u2019 character that ultimately acted as a dropper. When the macro was executed, the hex bytes were split, converted to binary, and dropped onto disk as an executable. The first few lines of this functionality are shown below:\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 9. Macro from malicious documents associated with CARROTBALL.\r\nIn this case, the dropped binary was a new type of downloader we have dubbed CARROTBALL. Its sole purpose was to serve as the main mechanism to facilitate the download and installation of the SYSCON backdoor. This is very similar to the CARROTBAT samples observed earlier on in this campaign and in the previous Fractured Block campaign (see technical analysis here). Additionally, of novel interest in this attack was the use of two separate FTP credential pairs to conduct active C2 operations. One credential pair was hardcoded in the dropped CARROTBALL binary and used to connect to the domain downplease.c1[.]biz to retrieve a CAB file renamed with a generic .dat extension.\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 10. Observed CARROTBALL FTP interaction.\r\nWhen extracted, the .cab file was found to contain two malicious batch files, two malicious dlls (one of which contained a custom base64 alphabet), and a second domain (lookplease.c1[.]biz) with a set of FTP login credentials encoded in the custom base64 alphabet. The contents of the cab file are as follows:\r\n\r\n\r\nFigure 11. Converted CAB file contents extracted from observed CARROTBALL FTP interaction.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nFile Name\r\nFunctionality\r\n\r\n\r\n42e874d96cb9046cd4113d04c1c5463b1d43a4e828ca872de11c08cd314e650f\r\nalive.bat\r\nInstall and establish persistence for core SYSCON backdoor component.\r\n\r\n\r\na761b47ab25dc2aa66b2f8ad4ab9636e40ebbcaf67f8a34f3524456c09f47d76\r\nbpu.dll\r\nUPX-packed system process injection mechanism to gain execution of alive.bat. Reserved for use against non-admin users.\r\n\r\n\r\nc3ac29e4b0c5e1a991d703769b94c0790fbf81fd38cf6acdb240c5246c2517ca\r\nmama.bat\r\nBatch file to delete assorted host based artifacts of malware. Deletes bpu.dll if running as Admin. Runs bpu.dll if not Admin.\r\n\r\n\r\nad63b8677c95792106f5af0b99af04e623146c6206125c93cf1ec9fbfeafaac9\r\nsyssec.bin\r\nCustom base64 encoded FTP credentials and C2 domain.\r\n\r\n\r\nbdd90ed7e40c8324894efe9600f2b26fd18b22dcbf3c72548fee647a81d3c099\r\nsyssec.dll\r\nCore SYSCON backdoor component.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 8. CAB file contents.\r\nWhile observing the malware\u2019s interaction with the second domain, lookplease.c1[.]biz, two text files were subsequently identified containing text encoded with the same custom base64 alphabet used previously. When decoded, these files were found to contain additional commands to be executed on the infected host.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256\r\nFile Name\r\nRaw FIle Contents\r\nDecoded Command\r\n\r\n\r\nf3d3fa4c76adfabd239accb453512af33ae8667bf261758f402fff22d9df1f67\r\nGei All (0).txt\r\nFg37eqye0ee2eqse0e3SeY8evg3Geqhecy3-eqAexf32eUAe\r\ncmd \/c systeminfo\r\n\r\n\r\n4b8790e9cb2f58293c28e695bec0a35e2ebd2da8e151c7e8c4513a1508c8bc94\r\nGei All (1).txt\r\nFg37eqye0ee2eqse0e3GeqOevg31eqge\/y3SeYyeZfeD\r\ncmd \/c tasklist\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 9. SYSCON C2 file attributes.\r\nAt the time of the activity, both downplease.c1[.]biz and lookplease.c1[.]biz resolved to the IP address 185.176.43[.]94.\r\nAttribution\r\nKonni: Malware or Actor?\r\nOriginally, the name \u201cKonni\u201d was used to refer to a Remote Access Trojan utilized in targeted campaigns with strong links to North Korean interests. However, as additional campaigns began to appear with strongly overlapping TTPs yet did not feature the Konni RAT, specifically, some industry researchers simply began to adopt the \u201cKonni\u201d moniker to refer to the actors behind the aggregated set of activity. Unit 42 has followed this trend, and now refers to the \u201cKonni Group\u201d as such.\r\nKonni\u2019s Ties to Fractured Statue\r\nAs prominently documented by Cisco Talos, the first Konni Group activity was a sustained information stealing\/RAT distribution campaign spanning between 2014 and 2017. Throughout 2018, Unit 42 released several blogs on Konni Group activity, and subsequently identified two new malware families the group was using in the attacks, dubbed NOKKI and CARROTBAT, respectively. Now, in 2019, Unit 42\u2019s continued observation of targeted CARROTBAT activity (in addition to the new malware CARROTBALL being used during the same campaign) could indicate that both are still in use by the Konni Group, as thematically linked elements of Konni Group TTPs include:\r\n\r\n \tTargeting individuals\/organizations who have interest in, are directly linked to, or conduct business in North Korea (corroborated by previous research by Unit 42).\r\n \tUtilizing malicious document phishing lures containing subject matter pertaining to North Korea (corroborated by previous research by Unit 42).\r\n \tIteratively increasing the type and complexity of their payload delivery mechanisms (from their initial use of simple Base64 strings as reported by Trend Micro, then later leveraging CARROTBAT, and now leveraging CARROTBALL)\r\n\r\nHowever, there are non-trivial obstacles to obtaining a high-confidence attribution to the Konni Group, namely the fact that previous blogs produced by Unit 42 and other researchers contain a great deal of technical detail about the group\u2019s operations, and copycat actors may attempt to emulate previously observed TTPs to hinder attribution efforts or perform false-flag operations.\r\n\r\nIn light of these factors, Unit 42 assesses with moderate confidence that this activity is related to the Konni Group.\r\nConclusion\r\nOverall, the Fractured Statue campaign provides clear evidence that the TTPS discovered in Fractured Block are still relevant, and that the group behind the attacks still appears to be active. Additionally, development and use of the new downloader, CARROTBALL, alongside the more commonly observed malware delivery mechanism, CARROTBAT, may indicate that the previous methods employed by the group to successfully infect their targets are becoming less effective. The Adversary Playbook for the activity described in this blog can be found here.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat in the following ways:\r\n\r\n* AutoFocus customers can track these samples with the FracturedStatue, SYSCON, KONNI, CARROTBAT and CARROTBALL tags.\r\n\r\n* WildFire detects all files mentioned in this report with malicious verdicts.\r\n\r\n* Cortex XDR blocks all of the files currently associated with the Fractured Block campaign.\r\nIOCS:\r\nMalicious Documents with CARROTBAT:\r\na4f858c6b54683d3b7455c9adcf2bb6b7ddc1f4d35d0f8f38a0f131c60d1790f\r\n\r\ned63e84985e1af9c4764e6b6ca513ec1c16840fb2534b86f95e31801468be67a\r\n\r\n9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225\r\n\r\n4c201f9949804e90f94fe91882cb8aad3e7daf496a7f4e792b9c7fed95ab0726\r\n\r\n63c3817a5e9984aaf59e8a61ddd54793ffed11ac5becef438528447f6b2823af\r\nMalicious Document with CARROTBALL:\r\nc1a9b923fc1f81d69bd0494d296c75887e4a0f9abfc1cdfbfa9c0f4ab6c95db7\r\nCARROTBALL Downloader:\r\n56924402a17393e542f6bf5b02cd030cc3af73bc2e1c894a133cebb2ca9405ee\r\nSYSCON Samples:\r\nceb8093507911939a17c6c7b39475f5d4db70a9ed3b85ef34ff5e6372b20a73e\r\n\r\n52ba17b90244a46e0ef2a653452b26bcb94f0a03b999c343301fef4e3c1ec5d2\r\n\r\n4958fe8c106200da988c22957821513efd05803460e8e5fcfedb5cbca8d87a5b\r\n\r\n7d2b1af486610a45f78a573af9a9ad00414680ff8e958cfb5437a1b140acb60c\r\n\r\nbdd90ed7e40c8324894efe9600f2b26fd18b22dcbf3c72548fee647a81d3c099\r\nAssociated SYSCON C2 Files:\r\nf3d3fa4c76adfabd239accb453512af33ae8667bf261758f402fff22d9df1f67\r\n\r\n4b8790e9cb2f58293c28e695bec0a35e2ebd2da8e151c7e8c4513a1508c8bc94\r\n\r\nad63b8677c95792106f5af0b99af04e623146c6206125c93cf1ec9fbfeafaac9\r\n\r\nc3ac29e4b0c5e1a991d703769b94c0790fbf81fd38cf6acdb240c5246c2517ca\r\n\r\na761b47ab25dc2aa66b2f8ad4ab9636e40ebbcaf67f8a34f3524456c09f47d76\r\n\r\n42e874d96cb9046cd4113d04c1c5463b1d43a4e828ca872de11c08cd314e650f\r\nInfrastructure:\r\nDomain: handicap[.]eu5[.]org\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: 69.197.143[.]12\r\n\r\nDomain: panda2019[.]eu5[.]org\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: 162.253.155[.]226\r\n\r\nDomain: downplease[.]c1[.]biz\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: 185.176.43[.]94\r\n\r\nDomain: lookplease[.]c1[.]biz\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: 185.176.43[.]94\r\nAdditional CARROTBALL Samples Identified on VirusTotal:\r\n6fa895d0472e87dea3c5c5bd6774488d2d7fe409ff9ae83870be3740fdfd40e8\r\n\r\nDomain: downyes[.]c1[.]biz\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: Unavailable\/unknown\r\n\r\n989c042ab9a07b11026bce78dc091f25fa51cb5e310c668904afc7939b197624\r\n\r\nDomain: downplease[.]c1[.]biz\r\n\r\nIP Resolution: 185.176.43[.]94\r\n\r\n&nbsp;","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Adrian     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x

</script>

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/06_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" title="Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:breadcrumb:Malware">Malware</a></li> </ul>
            </div>            <div class="ab__title">
              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Malware"><span class="ab-title__pre">Malware</span></a> 
              <h1>The Fractured Statue Campaign: U.S. Government Agency Targeted in Spear-Phishing Attacks</h1>
              <div class="ab__video">
              <span class="duration"> 
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-clock.svg" alt="Clock Icon"><span class="span-reading-time rt-reading-time"><span class="rt-label rt-prefix"></span> <span class="rt-time"> 9</span> <span class="rt-label rt-postfix"></span></span> min read              </span>
                              </div>          
              <div class="ab-lc__wrapper">
                <span class="ab-title__pre">Related Products</span><div class="ab__link-cards"><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/advanced-wildfire/" style="--card-color: #ffcb06" role="link" title="Advanced WildFire" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Advanced WildFire"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Advanced WildFire icon">Advanced WildFire</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cortex-xdr/" style="--card-color: #00cc66" role="link" title="Cortex XDR" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Cortex XDR"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/cortex_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cortex XDR icon">Cortex XDR</a></div>              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Adrian McCabe" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/amccabepaloaltonetworks-com/">Adrian McCabe</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>23 January, 2020 at 6:00 AM PST</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Malware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/">Malware</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Threat Research" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/">Threat Research</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:CARROTBALL" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/carrotball/">CARROTBALL</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:CARROTBAT" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/carrotbat/">CARROTBAT</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Fractured Statue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/fractured-statue/">Fractured Statue</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:KONNI" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/konni/">KONNI</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:phishing" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/">Phishing</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks:hero:Syscon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/syscon/">Syscon</a></li></ul></div>

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/the-fractured-statue-campaign-u-s-government-targeted-in-spear-phishing-attacks/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Between July and October 2019, Unit 42 observed several malware families typically associated with the Konni Group (see <a href="#Attribution">Attribution</a> section below for more details) used to primarily target a US government agency, using the ongoing and heightened geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea to lure targets into opening malicious email attachments. The malware families used in this campaign consisted mainly of malicious documents featuring CARROTBAT downloaders with SYSCON payloads, but also included a new malware downloader Unit 42 has dubbed CARROTBALL.</p>
<p>CARROTBALL, initially discovered in an attack during October 2019, is a simple FTP downloader utility which facilitates the installation of SYSCON, a full-featured Remote Access Trojan (RAT) which leverages FTP for Command and Control (C2). It was found embedded in a malicious Word document sent as a phishing lure to a US government agency and two non-US foreign nationals professionally associated with North Korea.</p>
<p>Throughout the course of the campaign, Unit 42 ultimately observed a total of six unique malicious document lures being sent as attachments from four unique Russian email addresses to 10 unique targets. The subject matter of the lures featured articles written in Russian pertaining to ongoing geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea. Of those malicious documents, five contained CARROTBAT downloaders, and one contained a CARROTBALL downloader. All malicious second stage payloads were SYSCON.</p>
<p>While this campaign does demonstrate some evolution in the actor’s tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) with the use of a new downloader family and new malicious code in the form of Word Document macros, the majority of its attributes bear a strong resemblance to the Fractured Block campaign <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-the-fractured-block-campaign-carrotbat-malware-used-to-deliver-malware-targeting-southeast-asia/">previously reported by Unit 42 in November 2018</a>. As such, Unit 42 has dubbed this campaign Fractured Statue. The Adversary Playbook for the activity described in this blog can be found <a href="https://pan-unit42.github.io/playbook_viewer/?pb=konni">here</a>.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" width="2203" height="906" class="wp-image-103342 aligncenter" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118.png" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118.png 2203w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-300x123.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-1024x421.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-768x316.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-1536x632.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-2048x842.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-900x370.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-118-370x152.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2203px) 100vw, 2203px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 1. Fractured Statue Campaign Timeline</em></span></p>
<h3>Opening Wave of Attacks</h3>
<p>Between July 15th, 2019 and July 17th, 2019, spear phishing emails were sent to a total of five individuals at a US government agency from the email addresses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kargarnova@mail[.]ru</span>. The spear phishing emails utilized three different email subjects with malicious macro documents attached with the same name; all file names were written in Russian. Further, all of the malicious documents contained articles written in Russian pertaining to ongoing geopolitical relations issues surrounding North Korea. The documents themselves were rather generic and had no embedded image enticements to enable macros. They did, however, leverage second-stage downloader components consistent with known CARROTBAT samples, and almost all of them featured SYSCON payloads. The first pages of each of these documents are shown below:</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103366" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-788x1024.png" alt="" width="600" height="780" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-788x1024.png 788w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-231x300.png 231w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-768x998.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-900x1170.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-370x481.png 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-2.-First-page-of-initial-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png 1128w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 2. First page of initial malicious document observed in the campaign.</span> </em></span></p>
<p><em>Associated with CARROTBAT.</em></p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.4409%;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 34.7863%;">Subject</td>
<td style="width: 10.1425%;">Sender</td>
<td style="width: 9.63956%;">Translated Subject</td>
<td style="width: 7.29254%;">File name</td>
<td style="width: 6.70578%;">Translated File Name</td>
<td style="width: 17.8541%;">Initial C2 Domain</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.4409%;">4c201f9949804e90f94fe91882cb8aad3e7daf496a7f4e792b9c7fed95ab0726</td>
<td style="width: 34.7863%;">О ситуации на Корейском полуострове и перспекти вах диалога между США и К НДР</td>
<td style="width: 10.1425%;">0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru</td>
<td style="width: 9.63956%;">On the situation on the Korean Peninsula and the prospects for dialogue between the USA and the PDR</td>
<td style="width: 7.29254%;">О ситуации на Корейском</td>
<td style="width: 6.70578%;">About the situation in Korean</td>
<td style="width: 17.8541%;">handicap.eu5[.]org</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 1. First phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103370" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-741x1024.png" alt="" width="600" height="829" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-741x1024.png 741w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-217x300.png 217w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-768x1061.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-900x1244.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-370x511.png 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-3.-First-page-of-second-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png 1094w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 3. First page of second malicious document observed in the campaign.</em></span></p>
<p><em> Associated with CARROTBAT.</em></p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 22.2979%;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 30.2128%;">Subject</td>
<td style="width: 13.2766%;">Sender</td>
<td style="width: 6.80851%;">Translated Subject</td>
<td style="width: 7.40426%;">File name</td>
<td style="width: 6.80851%;">Translated File Name</td>
<td style="width: 15.8298%;">Initial C2 Domain</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 22.2979%;">63c3817a5e9984aaf59e8a61ddd54793ffed11ac5becef438528447f6b2823af</td>
<td style="width: 30.2128%;">Продлится ли мирная пауз а на Корейском полуостро ве до 2024 года</td>
<td style="width: 13.2766%;">0tdelkorei@mail[.]ru</td>
<td style="width: 6.80851%;">Will there be a peaceful pause on the Korean Peninsula until 2024?</td>
<td style="width: 7.40426%;">Продлится ли мирная пауз</td>
<td style="width: 6.80851%;">Will the peace breaks last</td>
<td style="width: 15.8298%;">handicap.eu5[.]org</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 2. Second phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103372" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-794x1024.png" alt="" width="600" height="774" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-794x1024.png 794w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-233x300.png 233w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-768x991.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-900x1161.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-370x477.png 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-4.-First-page-of-third-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign..png 1124w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 4. First page of third malicious document observed in the campaign.</span> </em></p>
<p><em>Associated with CARROTBAT.</em></p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 47px;">
<td style="width: 553.333px; height: 47px;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 116px; height: 47px;">Subject</td>
<td style="width: 158.667px; height: 47px;">Sender</td>
<td style="width: 97.3333px; height: 47px;">Translated Subject</td>
<td style="width: 52px; height: 47px;">File name</td>
<td style="width: 76px; height: 47px;">Translated File Name</td>
<td style="width: 134.667px; height: 47px;">Initial C2 Domain</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 143px;">
<td style="width: 553.333px; height: 143px;">9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225</td>
<td style="width: 116px; height: 143px;">Россия – КНДР – РК – тор гово-экономические связ и – инвестиции.</td>
<td style="width: 158.667px; height: 143px;">kargarnova@mail[.]ru</td>
<td style="width: 97.3333px; height: 143px;">“Russia - DPRK - RK - trade and economic ties and - investments.”</td>
<td style="width: 52px; height: 143px;">Россия – КНДР – РК – тор</td>
<td style="width: 76px; height: 143px;">Russia - DPRK - RK - tor</td>
<td style="width: 134.667px; height: 143px;">handicap.eu5[.]org</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 3. Third phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<h3>Second Wave</h3>
<p>Roughly one month later, beginning on August 15, 2019 and ending on September 14, 2019, the second wave of CARROTBAT attacks occurred against three additional email addresses at the same government agency. One attack featured the same sender and malicious document but had a different subject and filename. The other two emails contained a previously unseen malicious document and featured a mix of Russian and English languages in both the document lures and the email correspondence.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 42.5532%;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 22.5339%;">Subject</td>
<td style="width: 8.60727%;">Sender</td>
<td style="width: 17.2147%;">File name</td>
<td style="width: 15.2804%;">Initial C2 Domain</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 42.5532%;">9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225</td>
<td style="width: 22.5339%;">Russia – North Korea – Republic of Korea – trade and economic relations – investments.</td>
<td style="width: 8.60727%;">kargarnova@mail[.]ru</td>
<td style="width: 17.2147%;">Russia – North Korea – Republic of Korea</td>
<td style="width: 15.2804%;">handicap.eu5[.]org</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 4. Fourth phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103375" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-794x1024.png" alt="" width="600" height="774" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-794x1024.png 794w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-233x300.png 233w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-768x991.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-900x1161.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT.-370x477.png 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-5.-First-page-of-fourth-malicious-document-observed-in-the-campaign.-Associated-with-CARROTBAT..png 1124w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 6. Sixth phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<h3>Final Attempt</h3>
<p>On October 29, 2019, one of the same individuals targeted in the second wave of attacks was targeted again with a malicious document, though in this attack the sender was different and the document lure did not feature CARROTBAT. Also of note is that the lure in this attack did feature a more traditional “enable macro” cover page, but was then followed by additional pages in Russian that thematically matched with the documents found in the rest of the campaign.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" width="548" height="635" class="wp-image-103354 aligncenter" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-124.png" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-124.png 548w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-124-259x300.png 259w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/word-image-124-370x429.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 548px) 100vw, 548px" /></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 7. First page of sixth malicious document observed in the campaign. Associated with CARROTBALL.</em></span></p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>SHA256</td>
<td>Subject</td>
<td>Sender</td>
<td>Translated Subject</td>
<td>File name</td>
<td>Translated File Name</td>
<td>Initial C2 Domain</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>c1a9b923fc1f81d69bd0494d296c75887e4a0f9abfc1cdfbfa9c0f4ab6c95db7</td>
<td>Инвестиционный климат Северной Кореи.</td>
<td>pryakhin20l0@mail[.]ru</td>
<td>“The investment climate of North Korea.”</td>
<td>Инвестиционный климат С</td>
<td>Investment climate C</td>
<td>downplease.c1[.]biz</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 7. Seventh phishing attempt details.</em></span></p>
<p>Also interesting to note is that the sender added multiple recipients to their email; one was an individual at a US government agency, and the other two individuals were non-US foreign nationals professionally associated with ongoing activities in North Korea.</p>
<h3>Technical Analysis</h3>
<p>With the exception of the October 2019 attack, all of the malicious documents found in this campaign featured the following macro code snippet of interest:</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-8.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBAT..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103420" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-8.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBAT..png" alt="" width="600" height="399" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-8.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBAT..png 748w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-8.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBAT.-300x200.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-8.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBAT.-370x246.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 8. Macro from malicious documents associated with CARROTBAT.</em></span></p>
<p>When executed, this code will:</p>
<ul>
<li>Determine whether the victim’s host machine is running Windows with an x86 or x64 architecture.</li>
<li>Parse the contents of a corresponding textbox within the document and convert it to a command line argument specific to the Windows architecture on the victim’s machine.</li>
<li>Execute the command.</li>
<li>Clear the contents of the textboxes and save the document.</li>
</ul>
<p>As previously mentioned, all samples featuring the macros above also featured CARROTBAT as a second stage downloader.</p>
<p>The October 2019 attack, however, differed significantly from the previous ones. Instead of reading from the contents of the document itself, the macros leveraged an embedded Windows executable in the form of hex bytes delimited via the ‘|’ character that ultimately acted as a dropper. When the macro was executed, the hex bytes were split, converted to binary, and dropped onto disk as an executable. The first few lines of this functionality are shown below:</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2.png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103431" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-1024x657.png" alt="" width="600" height="385" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-1024x657.png 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-300x192.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-768x493.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-900x577.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2-370x237.png 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-9.-Macro-from-malicious-documents-associated-with-CARROTBALL.-2.png 1244w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 9. Macro from malicious documents associated with CARROTBALL.</em></span></p>
<p>In this case, the dropped binary was a new type of downloader we have dubbed CARROTBALL. Its sole purpose was to serve as the main mechanism to facilitate the download and installation of the SYSCON backdoor. This is very similar to the CARROTBAT samples observed earlier on in this campaign and in the previous Fractured Block campaign (see technical analysis <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-the-fractured-block-campaign-carrotbat-malware-used-to-deliver-malware-targeting-southeast-asia/">here</a>). Additionally, of novel interest in this attack was the use of two separate FTP credential pairs to conduct active C2 operations. One credential pair was hardcoded in the dropped CARROTBALL binary and used to connect to the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">downplease.c1[.]biz</span> to retrieve a CAB file renamed with a generic .dat extension.</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103379" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png" alt="" width="600" height="360" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png 920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-300x180.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-768x461.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-900x540.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-10.-Observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-370x222.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 10. Observed CARROTBALL FTP interaction.</em></span></p>
<p>When extracted, the .cab file was found to contain two malicious batch files, two malicious dlls (one of which contained a custom base64 alphabet), and a second domain (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lookplease.c1[.]biz</span>) with a set of FTP login credentials encoded in the custom base64 alphabet. The contents of the cab file are as follows:</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-103426" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png" alt="" width="600" height="194" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction..png 938w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-300x97.png 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-768x249.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-900x292.png 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Figure-11.-Converted-CAB-file-contents-extracted-from-observed-CARROTBALL-FTP-interaction.-370x120.png 370w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 11. Converted CAB file contents extracted from observed CARROTBALL FTP interaction.</em></span></p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 23px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 23px;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 23px;">File Name</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 23px;">Functionality</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 167px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 167px;">42e874d96cb9046cd4113d04c1c5463b1d43a4e828ca872de11c08cd314e650f</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 167px;">alive.bat</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 167px;">Install and establish persistence for core SYSCON backdoor component.</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 287px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 287px;">a761b47ab25dc2aa66b2f8ad4ab9636e40ebbcaf67f8a34f3524456c09f47d76</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 287px;">bpu.dll</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 287px;">UPX-packed system process injection mechanism to gain execution of alive.bat. Reserved for use against non-admin users.</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 287px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 287px;">c3ac29e4b0c5e1a991d703769b94c0790fbf81fd38cf6acdb240c5246c2517ca</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 287px;">mama.bat</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 287px;">Batch file to delete assorted host based artifacts of malware. Deletes bpu.dll if running as Admin. Runs bpu.dll if not Admin.</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 143px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 143px;">ad63b8677c95792106f5af0b99af04e623146c6206125c93cf1ec9fbfeafaac9</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 143px;">syssec.bin</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 143px;">Custom base64 encoded FTP credentials and C2 domain.</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 95px;">
<td style="width: 26.6575%; height: 95px;">bdd90ed7e40c8324894efe9600f2b26fd18b22dcbf3c72548fee647a81d3c099</td>
<td style="width: 51.3283%; height: 95px;">syssec.dll</td>
<td style="width: 65.6714%; height: 95px;">Core SYSCON backdoor component.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 8. CAB file contents.</em></span></p>
<p>While observing the malware’s interaction with the second domain, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lookplease.c1[.]biz</span>, two text files were subsequently identified containing text encoded with the same custom base64 alphabet used previously. When decoded, these files were found to contain additional commands to be executed on the infected host.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 47px;">
<td style="width: 11.3722%; height: 47px;">SHA256</td>
<td style="width: 39.8497%; height: 47px;">File Name</td>
<td style="width: 33.2706%; height: 47px;">Raw FIle Contents</td>
<td style="width: 14.3797%; height: 47px;">Decoded Command</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 71px;">
<td style="width: 11.3722%; height: 71px;">f3d3fa4c76adfabd239accb453512af33ae8667bf261758f402fff22d9df1f67</td>
<td style="width: 39.8497%; height: 71px;">Gei All (0).txt</td>
<td style="width: 33.2706%; height: 71px;">Fg37eqye0ee2eqse0e3SeY8evg3Geqhecy3-eqAexf32eUAe</td>
<td style="width: 14.3797%; height: 71px;">cmd /c systeminfo</td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 71px;">
<td style="width: 11.3722%; height: 71px;">4b8790e9cb2f58293c28e695bec0a35e2ebd2da8e151c7e8c4513a1508c8bc94</td>
<td style="width: 39.8497%; height: 71px;">Gei All (1).txt</td>
<td style="width: 33.2706%; height: 71px;">Fg37eqye0ee2eqse0e3GeqOevg31eqge/y3SeYyeZfeD</td>
<td style="width: 14.3797%; height: 71px;">cmd /c tasklist</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 9. SYSCON C2 file attributes.</em></span></p>
<p>At the time of the activity, both <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">downplease.c1[.]biz</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lookplease.c1[.]biz</span> resolved to the IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.176.43[.]94</span>.</p>
<h3><a id="Attribution"></a>Attribution</h3>
<h5><strong>Konni: Malware or Actor?</strong></h5>
<p>Originally, the name “Konni” was used to refer to a Remote Access Trojan utilized in targeted campaigns with strong links to North Korean interests. However, as additional campaigns began to appear with strongly overlapping TTPs yet did not feature the Konni RAT, specifically, some industry researchers simply began to adopt the “Konni” moniker to refer to the actors behind the aggregated set of activity. Unit 42 has followed this trend, and now refers to the “Konni Group” as such.</p>
<h5><strong>Konni’s Ties to Fractured Statue</strong></h5>
<p>As prominently <a href="https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2017/05/konni-malware-under-radar-for-years.html">documented by Cisco Talos</a>, the first Konni Group activity was a sustained information stealing/RAT distribution campaign spanning between 2014 and 2017. Throughout 2018, Unit 42 released several blogs on Konni Group activity, and subsequently identified two new malware families the group was using in the attacks, dubbed <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-new-konni-malware-attacking-eurasia-southeast-asia/">NOKKI</a> and <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-the-fractured-block-campaign-carrotbat-malware-used-to-deliver-malware-targeting-southeast-asia/">CARROTBAT</a>, respectively. Now, in 2019, Unit 42’s continued observation of targeted CARROTBAT activity (in addition to the new malware CARROTBALL being used during the same campaign) could indicate that both are still in use by the Konni Group, as thematically linked elements of Konni Group TTPs include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Targeting individuals/organizations who have interest in, are directly linked to, or conduct business in North Korea (corroborated by previous research by Unit 42).</li>
<li>Utilizing malicious document phishing lures containing subject matter pertaining to North Korea (corroborated by previous research by Unit 42).</li>
<li>Iteratively increasing the type and complexity of their payload delivery mechanisms (from their initial use of simple Base64 strings <a href="https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/syscon-backdoor-uses-ftp-as-a-cc-channel/">as reported by Trend Micro</a>, then later leveraging CARROTBAT, and now leveraging CARROTBALL)</li>
</ul>
<p>However, there are non-trivial obstacles to obtaining a high-confidence attribution to the Konni Group, namely the fact that previous blogs produced by Unit 42 and other researchers contain a great deal of technical detail about the group’s operations, and copycat actors may attempt to emulate previously observed TTPs to hinder attribution efforts or perform false-flag operations.</p>
<p>In light of these factors, Unit 42 assesses with moderate confidence that this activity is related to the Konni Group.</p>
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Overall, the Fractured Statue campaign provides clear evidence that the TTPS discovered in Fractured Block are still relevant, and that the group behind the attacks still appears to be active. Additionally, development and use of the new downloader, CARROTBALL, alongside the more commonly observed malware delivery mechanism, CARROTBAT, may indicate that the previous methods employed by the group to successfully infect their targets are becoming less effective. The Adversary Playbook for the activity described in this blog can be found <a href="https://pan-unit42.github.io/playbook_viewer/?pb=konni">here</a>.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat in the following ways:</p>
<p>* AutoFocus customers can track these samples with the <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.FracturedStatue">FracturedStatue</a>, <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.Syscon">SYSCON</a>, <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.KONNI">KONNI</a>, <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.CARROTBAT">CARROTBAT</a> and <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.CARROTBALL">CARROTBALL</a> tags.</p>
<p>* WildFire detects all files mentioned in this report with malicious verdicts.</p>
<p>* Cortex XDR blocks all of the files currently associated with the Fractured Block campaign.</p>
<h3><strong>IOCS:</strong></h3>
<h5><strong>Malicious Documents with CARROTBAT:</strong></h5>
<p>a4f858c6b54683d3b7455c9adcf2bb6b7ddc1f4d35d0f8f38a0f131c60d1790f</p>
<p>ed63e84985e1af9c4764e6b6ca513ec1c16840fb2534b86f95e31801468be67a</p>
<p>9dfe3afccada40a05b8b34901cb6a63686d209e2b92630596646dba8ee619225</p>
<p>4c201f9949804e90f94fe91882cb8aad3e7daf496a7f4e792b9c7fed95ab0726</p>
<p>63c3817a5e9984aaf59e8a61ddd54793ffed11ac5becef438528447f6b2823af</p>
<h5><strong>Malicious Document with CARROTBALL:</strong></h5>
<p>c1a9b923fc1f81d69bd0494d296c75887e4a0f9abfc1cdfbfa9c0f4ab6c95db7</p>
<h5><strong>CARROTBALL Downloader:</strong></h5>

<h5><strong>SYSCON Samples:</strong></h5>

<p>4958fe8c106200da988c22957821513efd05803460e8e5fcfedb5cbca8d87a5b</p>
<p>7d2b1af486610a45f78a573af9a9ad00414680ff8e958cfb5437a1b140acb60c</p>
<p>bdd90ed7e40c8324894efe9600f2b26fd18b22dcbf3c72548fee647a81d3c099</p>

<p>42e874d96cb9046cd4113d04c1c5463b1d43a4e828ca872de11c08cd314e650f</p>

<p>IP Resolution: 162.253.155[.]226</p>
<p>Domain: downplease[.]c1[.]biz</p>

              </div>

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of keylogger malware like KLogEXE and FPSpy.
